title: Advanced Prompt Engineering for Front-End Component Generation
summary: This workflow demonstrates a structured approach to generating complex front-end components using Large Language Models. By utilizing a four-part prompting framework (Role, Purpose, Requirements, Memory), the user generates a Vue.js Carousel component and subsequently refines the code through iterative debugging and CSS adjustments to achieve a functional result.

steps.action: Define Role and Purpose in Prompt
steps.reasoning: Establishing a specific persona (Senior Vue.js Engineer) and context (New Project) primes the LLM to adopt the correct level of expertise and tone.
Using a verbose, bulleted list of constraints (e.g., avoiding specific wrappers, defining animation logic) prevents the LLM from using unwanted libraries or patterns.
Providing specific helper functions and syntax examples (Vue 3 <script setup>) bridges knowledge cutoffs and enforces specific coding standards that the LLM might otherwise ignore.
Transferring the AI-generated code into the local development environment to assess functionality and identify integration issues.
Correcting minor syntax hallucinations, such as removing invalid 'export' keywords inside a script setup block, to make the code compilable.
Adjusting DOM structure and CSS properties (flex-shrink, container widths) to fix visual layout issues that the LLM could not perfectly predict without visual context.
Manually fixing navigation indices and button states to ensure the component behaves correctly during user interaction.

key_takeaways: The 'Role, Purpose, Requirements, Memory' framework is a reusable template for high-fidelity code generation.
Providing 'Memory' (existing code snippets or syntax examples) is crucial for guiding LLMs to use specific versions or patterns.
AI-generated code typically achieves 80-90% completion, requiring a human-in-the-loop for final debugging and logic refinement.
